<headline>
Greece/David vs Troika/Goliath
</headline>
<post id="p1" author="apspa11" datetime="2015-06-12T17:10:00">
Joseph Stiglitz, Thomas Piketty and Other World-Renowned Economists Demand End to Greek Austerity
The economists called their letter a “plea for economic sanity and humanity.”
BY Martin de Bourmont
In an essay published on Friday morning in the Financial Times, 26 of the world’s most renowned economic minds proclaimed their solidarity with Syriza, Greece’s ruling anti-austerity party.

The article’s authors—a group that includes Joseph Stiglitz, Thomas Piketty, Marcus Miller and former Prime Minister of Italy Massimo D’Alema—summarized their message as a “plea for economic sanity and humanity.” Arguing that the fate of the European Union depends on the ability of Greece and its creditor institutions to compromise, they demanded that the European Union provide “forbearance and finance to promote structural reform and financial recovery,” and that Greece demonstrate “credible commitment” to reform and playing “a positive role in the EU.”

At the center of the article is austerity’s failure to remedy Greece’s economic woes. “Austerity drastically reduces revenue from tax reform,” they write “and restricts the space for change to make administration accountable and socially efficient.” Moreover, they continue, “the constant concessions required by the government mean that Syriza is in danger of losing political support and thus its ability to create a program that will bring Greece out of the crisis.”

more: <a href="http://inthesetimes.com/article/18020/joseph-stiglitz-thomas-piketty-greece-syriza-austerity" target="_blank">http://inthesetimes.com/article/18020/joseph-stiglitz-thomas-piketty-greece-syriza-austerity</a>
</post>
<post id="p2" author="lornejnx" datetime="2015-06-13T14:54:00">

</post>
<post id="p3" author="apspa11" datetime="2015-06-13T20:12:00">
You're not paying attention. The situation is way beyond the niceties you point out (5 years of same-old-same-old predatory loans).
Greece told the troika to shove their money unless they renegotiate the terms - a position they are entitled to take.
The troika has refused - a position they are entitled to take.
Greece has the right to find other sources of money to service their debts/recovery. Most likely it will be from from the new kid on the block the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB).

The troika is, IMHO, desperate to prevent Greece from doing so as is the US. The AIIB is a direct challenge to IMF/WB hegemony and the world's capitalist nations do not want its poorer-nation victims receiving help/relief from a socialist China.
Next: the EU(the troika) has two choices, throw Greece out of the Union or blink.
Greece has set the agenda!
</post>

<post id="p5" author="lolahooter (levantina)" datetime="2015-06-13T22:25:00">
Think of it like this. Greece has done what they all do - borrowed to the hilt - and to make debt repayment they screw it out of the ones least able to fight back. The poor, pensioners, disabled.
Greece at last has elected a government who is no longer prepared to do this and is prepared to go to the wire rather than screw those who cant be screwed any more.
I am impressed and I hope they succeed because I'm sick of little people being sacrificed and crucified on the selfishness of their political and wealthy classes.
</post>

<post id="p9" author="apspa11" datetime="2015-06-14T17:37:00">
<quote orig_author="lornejnx">
They are now shut out of the credit markets.
</quote>
Ahh you have stumbled, unawares it appears, upon the rub.

The IMF/WB, etc, exist for one purpose - to regulate the world economy to serve the interests of the major capitalist nations. They were founded in 1944 when it became clear the Soviet Union would not be destroyed. That socialism would continue to compete with capitalism. The United States and United Kingdom played the major role in the creation in that they emerged from the war the strongest.

The role the banks were designed to play was made obvious with the Word Bank's loan to war torn France. In addition to repayment conditions France had to comply to the demand from the US and GB that it remove members associated with the Communist Party from France's coalition government. France complied.

(As an aside, the anti-French meme that occasionally surfaces here in the US has its roots in the hatred the US and GB had toward France for not doing to the French left after the war what Great Britain did to the Greek left freedom fighters as soon as the last Nazi was chased out of Greece)
So for some 70 years those banks dominated world finance.
But today the IMF/WB are no longer <b>the only<b> "credit markets."
And therein lies the rub that is chafing the EU, the US, GB, Wall Street, etc.
And that is were you haven't been paying attention. Greece, or any other nation being victimized by the austerity ghouls of IMF/WB, have <b>choices <b>.
</post>
<post id="p10" author="lolahooter (levantina)" datetime="2015-06-14T17:50:00">

<post id="p11" author="apspa11" datetime="2015-06-14T18:26:00">
<quote orig_author="lornejnx">
I think it will turn out badly for the Greeks.
</quote>
Ah the voice of surrender and obiesence.
The past 5 years have been bad for Greece because the former government conceded their responsibility to their citizens to the banking and corporate vultures presented by the Troika.
And the Troika has been faithful to <b>its<b> masters.
But I don't believe Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis visited China and Russia to take in the sights recently. And niether does the Troika.
In struggle there is risk, but as many of us said in the 50s/60s, dare to struggle, dare to win.
Greece has got up off its knees. It has already scored an important victory.
</post>
<post id="p12" author="apspa11" datetime="2015-06-14T19:06:00">
Even though they have have been ill-served (an understatement by any measure) by the previous administration the P.M. Tsipras and Greece has not gone off half-cocked.
They have done their homework.
Given the unmitigated disaster of Ukraine the EU and the US/NATO are defending the actions of the Troika from a greatly weakened position both public opinion wise and diplomatically.

Calls from EU nations for the end to sanctions against Russia are reaching fever pitch because the sanctions are hurting their trade more that any pain being put on Russia, while other nations have rejected Obama's "order" to boycott attending/joining China's new Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB).
The AIIB is an in-your-face challenge to the IMF/WB global hegemony.
All in all not a good environment for the world's once dominant players to be attempting to push smaller nations around.
Greece has and is playing its cards well.
By all means be impressed (but hold your breath a little longer).
</post>

</post>

<post id="p17" author="lolahooter (levantina)" datetime="2015-06-15T22:43:00">
Still crossed, Theres a lot of undeclared issues but I hadn't factored that one in.
This is interesting and ongoing but not much reported. Enter the panda.

<a href="http://www.eurasiareview.com/25052015-three-risks-for-chinas-silk-road-investments-in-greece-oped/" target="_blank">http://www.eurasiareview.com/25052015-three-risks-for-chinas-silk-road-investments-in-greece-oped/</a>
And Im sure the EU finds this a bit of a pantsfiller. It certainly puts bargaining power in a few countries, hmmmn?
<a href="http://thediplomat.com/2015/06/unequal-partners-china-and-russia-in-eurasia/" target="_blank">http://thediplomat.com/2015/06/unequal-partners-china-and-russia-in-eurasia/</a>
<b>Mediterranean Cooperation<b>

But the unequal Sino-Russian partnership derives its momentum from more than economics. Over the last few years the Mediterranean Sea has taken on strategic importance for Beijing. The Mediterranean has 70 per cent of the world’s energy resources, which could help sustain China’s progress. Moreover, China’s global ambitions and its wish to diversify its markets and sources of energy have steered its economic and strategic interests westwards, outside of Asia to the coasts of southern Europe, northern Africa, and the Persian Gulf.

The Mediterranean marks the western end of China’s New Silk Road, which is designed to link China to markets across Central Asia and into Europe and the Middle East. The Silk Road needs a western outlet to the sea. So Chinese companies are contributing to the modernization of Mediterranean ports, in places like <b>Piraeus (Greece) Marseilles (France) and Barcelona (Spain). In Israel, China is building railway lines connecting Tel Aviv and Haifa on the Mediterranean coast to Eilat, on the northern end of the strategically important Red Sea, one of the sea lanes connecting Europe, the Persian Gulf and East Asia<b>. In Africa, China is developing Port Sudan with a view to improving its shipping facilities in the Red Sea, East Africa, and the Horn of Africa areas.

Economic interests could give impetus to the expansion of China’s military presence in the Mediterranean. Cooperating with Russia, China could compete with Western navies for influence in the Mediterranean.
</post>

<post id="p20" author="apspa11" datetime="2015-06-17T02:48:00">
Thanks for the links.
A critical word about the Diplomat link if you don't mind (not a reflection on you let me hasten to say - sometimes its difficult to separate the wheat from the chafe).

China and Russia are engaged in normal, every day economic activities that are mutually beneficial to each other. All nations do so when and if they can. Yet the article strives to make it appear some kind of conspiracy aimed at the United States. Consider the article's opening thought:
"Recent strategic shifts by China and Russia simultaneously – and paradoxically – mark closer ties, challenges to the U.S., an unequal partnership, and rivalry between them in Eurasia."
Note the use of words like strategic, challenges, rivalry. Ohh the horror of signing trade agreements, don't you know.
Then there is this paragraph:

"China and Russia have much in common. Both are authoritarian states who see the United States as a threat to their power. Both make territorial claims on neighboring countries, and maintain a diplomatic silence over each other’s ambitions over territories including Ukraine, Tibet, Japan, and the Philippines. Their penchant for saber-rattling and conquest leaves them a lonely but threatening and powerful twosome. Both are increasing military spending at a time when America and its NATO allies are cutting defense budgets. And China and Russia have much to offer each other. Both benefit from trade in national currencies. Both are members of the emerging markets group known as BRICS, the Chinese-sponsored Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO). However, China’s giant economy gives it the advantage in each of these groups."
Let's consider a few of its highlights (read lowlights):
"Both are authoritarian states who see the United States as a threat to their power."
Well its the United States that has sent its troops, the NATO forces associated military arms half-way around the world once again. There are no Chinese or Russian troops in Canada or Mexico.
"Their penchant for saber-rattling and conquest leaves them a lonely but threatening and powerful twosome."
Oh? I thought it was the US that did all that saber-rattling, conquest seeking, invading, bombing in Vietnam, Iraq killing a few million in recent history.

"Both are increasing military spending <a href="http://www.militarytimes.com/story/military/2015/04/14/china-russia-military-spending-surges/25770921/" target="_blank"><span style="color:#FF0000;">increasing military spending</span></a> at a time when America and its NATO allies are cutting defense budgets.

re America's and Its NATO allies cutting defense budgets, it is a distortion of the facts that misses being an outright lie by a cats-whisker. The US bears the brunt of NATO's budget. Last year Washington called upon the the other members to step up to the plate and raise their commitment to 2% of their GNP. The US cannot afford to carry that load alone (that is the reason the US/NATO joined the EU in their "invasion" of Ukraine - the US saw Ukraine as a new NATO member to squeeze money out of).

Those member nations the US tried to pry some funds from used the same finger in reply that Greece used in their reply to the EU/Troilka. The message to the US was, in effect, NATO is your baby you change its diaper we have our own problems.
So I guess if you put on the darkest rose-colored glasses you can find and light up joint you <b>might<b> believe America and its NATO allies are cutting defense budgets.
Best regards.
</post>
